C# - Basic

Created:2018-09-28  Last modified:2019-02-23

  • Types
  • Expression
  • Flow control
  • Class
  • References

  1. Types

    C# has two kinds of types: value types and reference types. But all types, including int, inherit from object.

    Value types

    Value types: primitive types, enum, struct, and null.

    1. sbyte, byte, short, ushort, int, uint, long, ulong, char, float, double, decimal (128bit high-percision decimal), bool
      (Java only has signed numbers)
    2. struct: Java does not have struct, this struct is similar to C/C++ struct

    Reference types

    reference types: Class, Interface, Array, and Delegate.

    1. Delegate (function pointer): delegate type represents references to methods with a particular parameter list and return type.

    Naming conventions

    1. namespace capitalized. (Java package use company ... lower case)

  2. Expression

    1. i++, i-- is allowed in C#, (Java, C, C++ as well), (Not allowed in Python)
    2. typeof(object): Obtains a Type object. Type is Class (Java Class class)
    3. (T)object: casting !!!!In C#, user can define how to cast variables. NEVER SEEN IN OTHER LANGUAGES.
    4. object as T: return a casted object. If cannot cast, return null.
    5. object is T: return true if object's type is T

  3. Flow control

    1. Switch (C# 7.0: any non-null expression), (C# 6.0: char, string, bool, integer, enum value)
      From JDK 7.0, java switch support String, and primitive types (cannot be null)
    2. Traditional if else if else, while, do-while, for
    3. foreach(string s in string_arr){} can be used if string_arr implemented System.Collections.IEnumerable
      for(String s: string_collections/string_arr){} for(Iterator<String> it = string_collections.iterator(); it.hasNext();) // java syntactic sugar for iterable collections
      for(int i = 0; i < string_arr.length; i++){} // for array.
    4. yield (python also has yield, and same function) is used to implement a iterator.

  4. Class

    C#'s class has some new features compared with Java. But most of these features are provided by C++.

    1. Access modifier
    2. Operator overload
    3. Indexer operator i.e. []
    4. Events (Different from Java Object notify, which is used for synchronization, C# events is a publisher-subscriber, which is used in the event-driven programming.)
    5. Finalizer (Destructor)
    6. Nested Types (Java inner class)

    Modifier for accessibility

    1. public: all
    2. protected: self and drived class
    3. internal: access limited to the current assembly (assembly is a .dll library or a .exe, it is not a namespace. (different from java.))
    4. protected internal: protected internal has a more border accessibility than internal. It is like protected || internal. 
                              // assembly1.dll
                            public class BaseClass
                            {
                               protected internal int myValue = 0;
                            }
                    
                              // assembly2.dll
                            public class SubClass:BaseClass{
                                public static void Main(){
                                    BaseClass bc = new BaseClass();
                                    // bc.myValue // error since different assembly
                                    SubClass a = new SubClass();
                                    a.myValue; // correct since drived class.
                                }
                            }
    5. private: inside the class
    6. private protected: subclass can access private field if the subclass and baseclass in the same assembly.
    Rules
    1. Default access modifier of class is Internal. And private for class member.
    2. Subclass's accessibility < Parent class e.g. Subclass Public and Parent class Internal is an error.

    Overload operator

    1. Overload Indexer. 
                              // []
                        class XXX{
                            public int this[int index] { // get, set, value are keywords in C#
                                get {
                                    return 0;
                                }
                                set {
                                    Console.WriteLine(value);
                                }
                            }
                        }
    2. Operator Overload.
      In C++, overloading a operator can be done as either a function member or a friend function. However, in C#, only the "friend function" like overloading is allowed. C# does not have "friend function" concept, it use public static method member. 
                              public class XXX{
                            public static string operator + (XXX a, XXX b){

                            }
                        }
    3. Casting Overload
      Here.

    Event with Function Delegate

    C# event subscribing can be done with IDE's drag. But also can be done programmatically with Delegate.
